filedesc.updatestmt:
The William Blake Archive is pleased to announce the publication of a digital edition of forty-seven monochrome wash drawings created by Blake between c. 1774 and c. 1786.
The use of monochrome washes to tint a pencil or pen and ink drawing offered eighteenth-century artists several advantages. They could register gradations in tone, from the white of the untouched paper to jet black, without the more time-consuming use of actual colors. No further work was required if the wash drawing was intended as a preliminary for an uncolored engraving. A monochrome wash could also be used to underlie subsequent applications of water colors, thereby darkening selected areas to create the illusion of depth or cast motifs in shadow.
As the works presented here show, Blake made full use of monochrome washes from his earliest years as an artist. When assigned by his engraving master, James Basire, to record tombs in Westminster Abbey c. 1774-75, Blake applied black and gray washes to tint many of his drawings (Objects 1-5). These carefully executed works could then be used as preliminaries for subsequent engravings by Basire’s workshop.
Blake’s monochrome washes during his first decade as an independent artist and engraver include several interrelated groups. The seven drawings of figures from Michelangelo’s Sistine ceiling (Objects 37-43) demonstrate how copying engravings of works by Renaissance masters helped Blake learn postures and gestures he would later use in his own compositions. Other drawings provide visual evidence of how Blake developed a design from early sketches to highly finished water colors or engravings. The recto/verso drawings, Two Sketches for “Joseph Making Himself Known to His Brethren” (Objects 34 and 35), are preliminaries for the finished water color in the Fitzwilliam Museum, one of three illustrations of the biblical story of Joseph that are among Blake’s finest pictorial works of the 1780s. The three Joseph water colors are in the Archive along with a water color preliminary for Joseph Ordering Simeon to be Bound. The evolution of one of Blake’s earliest original book illustrations, a frontispiece for Thomas Commins’ Elegy Set to Music of 1786, can be traced through three variant wash drawings (Objects 45-47) and a pencil sketch also in the Archive. The four wash versions of The Good Farmer reproduced here (Objects 16-19), in addition to two pen and ink drawings of the subject previously added to the Archive, show the complex ways Blake played variations on a theme as he worked toward a final version. No such finished work is known, and thus these drawings are our only record of Blake’s engagement with this subject. Similarly, for War Unchained by an Angel, Fire, Pestilence, and Famine Following, an untraced work Blake exhibited at the Royal Academy in 1784, we have only a preliminary study (Object 6).
Blake’s illustrations to his poem Tiriel of c. 1789 are among his most accomplished monochrome wash drawings. These have been published in the Archive as an independent group coordinated with the Tiriel manuscript.
As always, the William Blake Archive is a free site, imposing no access restrictions and charging no subscription fees. The site is made possible by the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill with the University of Rochester, the continuing support of the Library of Congress, and the cooperation of the international array of libraries and museums that have generously given us permission to reproduce works from their collections in the Archive.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Satan, the nude male figure at left, lunges or runs with arms raised toward the two figures at right, the nude female figure Sin and the crowned male figure Death. Satan and Death appear prepared to spear one another while Sin attempts to intervene. Satan has short hair and his mouth is open. He holds a spear in his right hand and a shield in his left. Facing right, he looks toward the pair of figures at right as he steps toward them with his extended right leg. The female figure Sin stands near the right side of the design and faces left to look toward Satan. She has long curly hair and is nude, at least above the waist. She raises both arms, which are slightly bent, and extends them left toward Satan. Her mouth is open. Her right leg appears to be raised and bent, as if she is stepping to the left. Her lower body is partially obscured by the heads of three dogs, most likely representing the three-headed Cerberus, who faces left with three open mouths. The details of the lower right corner are unclear, though Cerberus may be in a low boat atop an area of water(?). The third figure Death, who is nude, stands behind and to the left of Sin facing left as he walks or lunges to the left. He wears a spiky crown and has a beard. His mouth is open and his eyes are turned down and to the left. He may look toward Satan. Both arms are raised over his head where he holds a spear with at least his right hand. Shadows appear on Death's right leg and left arm as well as in the upper right corner behind him. Also in the upper right corner, several vertical lines, suggesting an indistinct architectural form such as a pillar, are visible. Flames are visible in the lower left corner of the design behind Satan.

component.illusobjdesc: Satan, the nude male figure at left, has short hair and his mouth is open. Facing right, he lunges or steps to the right with his right leg forward and left leg extended backward. Both of his arms are raised and he holds a spear in his right hand and a shield in his left. His left arm is bent. He appears to look at and point his spear at Death.

The female figure Sin stands or walks facing left near the right side of the design. She has long curly hair and is nude, at least above the waist. She raises both arms, which are slightly bent, and extends them horizontally to the left toward Satan, at whom she also looks. Her mouth is open. Her right leg appears to be raised and bent, as if she is stepping to the left. Her lower body is partially obscured by the heads of three dogs, most likely representing the three-headed dog Cerberus.

The heads of three dogs, most likely representing the three-headed Cerberus, face left beneath the female figure Sin. Their mouths are open and their teeth visible. The details of the lower right corner are unclear but the Cerberus may be in a boat atop water.

The details of the lower right corner are unclear, though Cerberus may be in a low boat atop an area of water(?). Alternatively, drapery may extend down from the hips of Sin into the lower right corner.

The third figure Death, who is nude, stands behind and to the left of Sin facing left as he walks or lunges to the left. He wears a spiky crown and has a beard. His mouth is open and his eyes are turned down and to the left. He may look toward Satan. Both arms are raised over his head where he holds a spear with at least his right hand. The spear is pointed toward Satan.
Shadows appear on Death's right leg and left arm as well as in the upper right corner behind him.
In the upper right corner, several vertical lines, suggesting an indistinct architectural form such as a pillar, are visible.
Flames are visible in the lower left corner of the design behind Satan and extend across the lower half of the plate.
